description: From Middle English bleren, from Middle Dutch bleren (“to bleat, cry, bawl, shout”) (Dutch blèren). Possibly ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleh₁- (“to bleat, cry”). Compare Dutch blaren.

examples: I can hardly hear you over the blare of the radio.

verbs.description: blare (third-person singular simple present blares, present participle blaring, simple past and past participle blared)

examples: The trumpet blaring in my ears gave me a headache.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to sound like the blare of a trumpet; to proclaim loudly.
examples: Police helicopters blared loudspeaker warnings about the smelly man.
